{{technical|date=November 2011}}
The '''Prandtl–Glauert transformation''' is a mathematical technique which allows solving certain [[Compressible flow|compressible]] flow problems by [[Incompressible flow|incompressible]]-flow calculation methods. It also allows applying incompressible-flow data to compressible-flow cases.
== Mathematical formulation == [[File:Prandtl-glauert-transform.png|thumb|Plot of the inverse [[Prandtl–Glauert factor]] <math>1/\beta</math> as a function of freestream [[Mach number]]. Notice the infinite limit at Mach 1.]]
Inviscid compressible flow over slender bodies is governed by linearized compressible small-disturbance potential equation:<ref>Kuethe, A.M. and Chow, C.Y., Foundations of Aerodynamics, Wiley, 1976</ref>
<math> \phi_{xx} \,+\, \phi_{yy} \,+\, \phi_{zz} \;=\; M_\infty^2 \phi_{xx} \;\;\;\; \mbox{(in flowfield)} </math>
together with the small-disturbance flow-tangency boundary condition.
<math> V_\infty \, n_x \,+\, \phi_y \, n_y \,+\, \phi_z \, n_z \;=\; 0 \;\;\;\; \mbox{(on body surface)} </math>
<math>M_\infty</math> is the freestream Mach number, and <math>n_x, n_y, n_z</math> are the surface-normal vector components. The unknown variable is the perturbation potential <math>\phi(x,y,z)</math>, and the total velocity is given by its gradient plus the freestream velocity <math>V_\infty</math> which is assumed here to be along <math>x</math>.
<math> \vec{V} \;=\; \nabla \phi + V_\infty \hat{x} \;=\; (V_\infty + \phi_x) \,\hat{x} \,+\, \phi_y \,\hat{y} \,+\, \phi_z \,\hat{z} </math>
The above formulation is valid only if the small-disturbance approximation applies ,<ref>Shapiro, A.H., Compressible Fluid Flow I, Wiley, 1953</ref>
<math> | \nabla \phi | \ll V_\infty </math>
and in addition that there is no transonic flow, approximately stated by the requirement that the local Mach number not exceed unity.
<math> \left[1 + (\gamma+1) \frac{\phi_x}{V_\infty} \right] M_\infty^2 \;<\; 1 </math>
The Prandtl–Glauert (PG) transformation uses the Prandtl–Glauert factor <math>\beta \equiv \sqrt{1 - M_\infty^2}</math>. It consists of scaling down all ''y'' and ''z'' dimensions and angle of attack by the factor of <math>\beta</math>, the potential by <math>\beta^2</math>, and the ''x'' component of the normal vectors by <math>\beta</math>:
<math> \begin{array}{rcl} \bar{x} &=& x \\ \bar{y} &=& \beta y \\ \bar{z} &=& \beta z \\ \bar{\alpha} &=& \beta \alpha \\ \bar{\phi} &=& \beta^2 \phi \end{array} </math>
This <math>\bar{x}\bar{y}\bar{z}</math> geometry will then have normal vectors whose x components are reduced by <math>\beta</math> from the original ones:
<math> \begin{array}{rcl} \bar{n}_{\bar{x}} &=& \beta n_x \\ \bar{n}_{\bar{y}} &=& n_y \\ \bar{n}_{\bar{z}} &=& n_z \end{array} </math>
The small-disturbance potential equation then transforms to the Laplace equation,
<math> \bar{\phi}_{\bar{x}\bar{x}} \,+\, \bar{\phi}_{\bar{y}\bar{y}} \,+\, \bar{\phi}_{\bar{z}\bar{z}} \;=\; 0 \;\;\;\; \mbox{(in flowfield)} </math>
and the flow-tangency boundary condition retains the same form.
<math> V_\infty \, \bar{n}_{\bar{x}} \,+\, \bar{\phi}_{\bar{y}} \, \bar{n}_{\bar{y}} \,+\, \bar{\phi}_{\bar{z}} \, \bar{n}_{\bar{z}} \;=\; 0 \;\;\;\; \mbox{(on body surface)} </math>
This is the incompressible potential-flow problem about the transformed <math>\bar{x}\bar{y}\bar{z}</math> geometry. It can be solved by incompressible methods, such as thin airfoil theory, vortex lattice methods, panel methods, etc. The result is the transformed perturbation potential <math>\bar{\phi}</math> or its gradient components <math>\bar{\phi}_{\bar{x}},\bar{\phi}_{\bar{y}},\bar{\phi}_{\bar{z}}</math> in the transformed space. The physical linearized pressure coefficient is then obtained by the inverse transformation
<math> C_p \;=\; - 2 \frac{\phi_x}{V_\infty} \;=\; -\frac{2}{\beta^2} \frac{\bar{\phi}_{\bar{x}}}{V_\infty} \;=\; \frac{1}{\beta^2} \bar{C}_p </math>
which is known as Göthert's rule <ref>Göthert, B.H. Plane and Three-Dimensional Flow at High Subsonic Speeds (Extension of the Prandtl Rule). NACA TM 1105, 1946.</ref>
== Results == For '''two-dimensional flow''', the net result is that <math>C_p</math> and also the lift and moment coefficients <math>c_l, c_m</math> are increased by the factor <math>1/\beta</math>:
:<math> \begin{array}{rcl} C_p &= \displaystyle \frac{C_{p0}} {\beta} \\ c_l &= \displaystyle \frac{c_{l0}} {\beta} \\ c_m &= \displaystyle \frac{c_{m0}} {\beta} \end{array} </math>
where <math>C_{p0}, c_{l0}, c_{m0}</math> are the incompressible-flow values for the '''original''' (unscaled) <math>xyz</math> geometry. This 2D-only result is known as the Prandtl Rule.<ref>Erich Truckenbrodt: Fluidmechanik Band 2, 4. Auflage, Springer Verlag, 1996, p. 178-179</ref>
For '''three-dimensional flows''', these simple <math>1/\beta</math> scalings do NOT apply. Instead, it is necessary to work with the scaled <math>\bar{x}\bar{y}\bar{z}</math> geometry as given above, and use the Göthert's Rule to compute the <math>C_p</math> and subsequently the forces and moments. No simple results are possible, except in special cases. For example, using [[Lifting-line theory|Lifting-Line Theory]] for a flat elliptical wing, the lift coefficient is
:<math> C_L = \frac{2 \pi \alpha}{\beta + 2/AR} </math>
where ''AR'' is the wing's aspect ratio. Note that in the 2D case where ''AR'' → ∞ this reduces to the 2D case, since in incompressible 2D flow for a flat airfoil we have <math>c_{l0} = 2 \pi \alpha</math>, as given by [[Airfoil|Thin airfoil theory]].
== Limitations == The PG transformation works well for all freestream Mach numbers up to 0.7 or so, or once transonic flow starts to appear.<ref>Shapiro, A.H., Compressible Fluid Flow I, Wiley, 1953</ref>
== History == [[Ludwig Prandtl]] had been teaching this transformation in his lectures for a while, however the first publication was in 1928 by [[Hermann Glauert]].<ref>H. Glauert, The Effect of Compressibility on the Lift of an Aerofoil. Proc. Roy. Soc. London. VOL. CXVIII, 1928, p. 113–119.</ref> The introduction of this relation allowed the design of aircraft which were able to operate in higher subsonic speed areas.<ref>[http://www.dglr.de/literatur/publikationen/pfeilfluegel/Kapitel1.pdf Meier, H.-U.: Die Entwicklung des Pfeilflügels, eine technische Herausforderung, Ludwig Prandtl memorial lecture, GAMM 2005, March 28th - April 1st 2005, Universität Luxemburg, Kapitel 1]</ref> Originally all these results were developed for 2D flow. B.H. Göthert<ref>Göthert, B.H. Plane and Three-Dimensional Flow at High Subsonic Speeds (Extension of the Prandtl Rule). NACA TM 1105, 1946.</ref> then pointed out that the geometry distortion of the PG transformation renders the simple 2D Prandtl Rule invalid for 3D, and properly stated the full 3D problem as described above.
The PG transformation was extended by [[Jakob Ackeret]] to supersonic-freestream flows. Like for the subsonic case, the supersonic case is valid only if there are no transonic effect, which requires that the body be slender and the freestream Mach is sufficiently far above unity.
== Singularity == {{Main|Prandtl–Glauert singularity}} Near the sonic speed <math>M_\infty \simeq 1</math> the PG transformation features a [[mathematical singularity|singularity]]. The singularity is also called the [[Prandtl–Glauert singularity]], and the flow resistance is calculated to approach infinity. In reality, aerodynamic and thermodynamic perturbations get amplified strongly near the sonic speed, but a singularity does not occur. An explanation for this is that the linearized small-disturbance potential equation above is not valid, since it assumes that there are only small variations in Mach number within the flow and absence of compression shocks and thus is missing certain nonlinear terms. However, these become relevant as soon as any part of the flow field accelerates above the speed of sound, and become essential near <math>M_\infty \simeq 1</math>. The more correct nonlinear equation does not exhibit the singularity.
==See also== * [[Ludwig Prandtl]] * [[Hermann Glauert]] * [[Jakob Ackeret]]
== Notes == <references/>

ROCI || Type |- | Less than 2 degrees latitude || Very small/midget |- | 2 to 3 degrees of latitude || Small |- | 3 to 6 degrees of latitude || Medium/Average |- | 6 to 8 degrees of latitude || Large |- | Over 8 degrees of latitude || Very large<ref name="JTWCsize">Joint Typhoon Warning Center. [http://www.usno.navy.mil/JTWC/frequently-asked-questions-1#tcsize Q: What is the average size of a tropical cyclone?] [[United States Navy]]. Retrieved on 2007-07-04.</ref> |- |}
The '''radius of outermost closed isobar''' ('''ROCI''') is one of the quantities used to determine the size of a [[tropical cyclone]]. It is determined by measuring the radii from the center of the storm to its outermost closed [[Contour line#Barometric pressure|isobar]] in four quadrants, which is then averaged to come up with a [[scalar (physics)|scalar]] value. It generally delimits the outermost extent of a tropical cyclone's wind circulation.<ref>FRÉDÉRIC MOUTON and OLA NORDBECK. [http://www.grid.unep.ch/product/publication/download/article_PREVIEW_TropCyclones.pdf Cyclone Database Manager.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718164557/http://www.grid.unep.ch/product/publication/download/article_PREVIEW_TropCyclones.pdf |date=2011-07-18 }} Retrieved on 2008-07-14.</ref>
Use of this measure has objectively determined that tropical cyclones in the northwest Pacific Ocean are the largest on earth on average, with [[North Atlantic hurricane|North Atlantic tropical cyclone]]s roughly half their size.<ref name="Merrill">Robert T. Merrill. [http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/112/7/pdf/i1520-0493-112-7-1408.pdf A Comparison of Large and Small Tropical Cyclones.] Retrieved on 2008-07-14.</ref> [[Active database]]s of ROCI are maintained by the [[National Hurricane Center]] for systems tracked in the eastern north Pacific and north Atlantic basins.
==Database== [[Image:Sandy Oct 25 2012 0400Z.JPG|thumb|Hurricane Sandy at peak intensity.]] Active databases of ROCI are maintained by the [[National Hurricane Center]] for systems tracked in the eastern north Pacific and north Atlantic basins, within a database known as the Extended Best Track Database. The values are determined in real-time every six hours. The eastern north Pacific database runs from 2001 to present, while the north Atlantic database runs from 1988 to present.<ref>Mark DeMaria (2009). [ftp://rammftp.cira.colostate.edu/demaria/ebtrk/ebtrk_atlc.txt Atlantic Extended Best Track Database.] [[Colorado State University]]. Retrieved on 2009-06-14.</ref> Other than these official databases, a global once-daily dataset was compiled for a 1984 research paper, which covered global tropical cyclones between 1957 and 1977.<ref name="Merrill"/> Previously, a database was created to determine ROCI values for the western north Pacific Ocean in 1972, using data from 1945 to 1968.<ref>K. S. Liu and Johnny C. L. Chan. [http://ams.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1175%2F1520-0493(1999)127%3C2992%3ASOTCAI%3E2.0.CO%3B2 Size of Tropical Cyclones as Inferred from ERS-1 and ERS-2 Data.] Retrieved on 2008-07-14.</ref> Another database with additional ROCI information is currently being modified at the [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] for use in matching ongoing tropical cyclones to past systems for the purposes of finding rainfall analogs to an ongoing event,<ref>David M. Roth and Kyle S. Griffin (2009-06-07). [http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/Cliqr_talk062009.ppt Cliqr Rainfall Analog.] [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]. Retrieved on 2009-06-14.</ref> which has fairly continuous data running back to 1959 for the north [[Atlantic ocean]].<ref name="CLIQR">{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/ebtrk_nhc_final.txt|author=David M. Roth|title=CLIQR Database|year=2013|accessdate=2013-01-04|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]}}</ref>
==Variation== Tropical cyclones tend to be smaller during the mid-summer, and largest in October in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. As tropical cyclones initially develop, the size of their ROCI initially contracts.<ref name="Brooks"/> Once tropical cyclones reach maturity, their isobaric patterns increase in size. During the mature stage, the broadening pressure pattern leads to some reduction in their [[maximum sustained wind]], but the extent of their tropical storm and hurricane-force winds is the most extensive within the storm's life cycle.<ref>{{cite book|title=Atlantic Hurricanes|author=Gordon E. Dunn and Banner I. Miller|publisher=[[Louisiana State University Press]]|date=1960|ASIN=B0006BM85S|page=32}}</ref> An increase in size is also noted as a tropical cyclone gains latitude.<ref name="Brooks">Edward Morgan Brooks (1945). [http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/13079/26336365.pdf?sequence=1 An Analysis of an Unusual Rainfall Distribution in a Hurricane.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403015659/http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/13079/26336365.pdf?sequence=1 |date=2015-04-03 }} [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. Retrieved on 2008-12-31.</ref> As tropical cyclones weaken, their ROCI values diminish. In general, the size of a tropical cyclone shows little relation to its intensity. Use of this measure has objectively determined that tropical cyclones in the northwest Pacific Ocean are the largest on earth on average, with [[North Atlantic hurricane|North Atlantic tropical cyclones]] roughly half their size.<ref name="Merrill"/>

'''Renewable energy law''' is a particular kind of [[energy law]], and relates primarily to the transactional legal and policy issues that surround the development, implementation, and commercialization of [[Renewable energy|renewable sources of energy]], such as solar, wind, geothermal and tidal. Renewable energy, (RE) law also relates to the land use, siting, and finance issues encountered by developers of renewable energy projects.
==Renewable energy support laws== Renewable energy law also encompasses policies that relate to renewable energy and legislative instruments that further encourage its growth. ===Feed-in tariffs=== One such form of legislation is [[feed-in tariffs]], which provide economic incentives to the developers of renewable energy projects by setting a fixed price for the sale of energy produced from renewable sources. Feed-in tariff laws also provide financial certainty, are more cost effective and less bureaucratic than other support schemes such as investment or production tax credits, quota based renewable portfolio standards (RPS), and auction mechanisms.<ref name="ref1">EC, 2005; Morris, 2007; Butler & Neuhoff, 2008</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Competitive auction mechanisms for the promotion renewable energy technologies: The case of the 50 MW photovoltaics projects in Cyprus|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364032114008399|work=Angeliki Kylili, Paris A. Fokaides|publisher=Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews|accessdate=30 October 2014|doi=10.1016/j.rser.2014.10.022|volume=42|pages=226–233}}</ref> In addition, the feed-in tariff generates more competition, more jobs, and more rapid deployment for manufacturing; it also does not pick technological winners, for instance between more mature [[wind power]] technology versus [[solar photovoltaics]] technology.<ref name="ref1" /> ===Renewable Portfolio standards=== This type of law is in force in 37 of the States within the United States, as well as Australia and a minority of European nations. It works by fixing the quantity of renewable electricity that must be produced, and leaving it to the market at what price this extra renewable electricity will be produced. This form of legislation typically employs a tradeable certificates mechanism, where 1 Megawatt Hour of electricity is equivalent to 1 renewable energy certificate. ===Auctions and tenders=== This form of renewable energy incentive is established by legislation and regulations and is increasingly popular throughout the world as a policy choice for governments. The details of the auction need to be carefully designed to prevent sub-optimal outcomes.
== Sector Regulation == The '''Role of the Sector Regulator''' is specified in the enabling legislation. For example, regulatory oversight of [[feed-in tariff]] programs is essential, whether the price is based on a predetermined number (and with some maximum capacity), an [[auction]]/[[bidding]] process, or avoided cost. In each case, the regulator monitors activities to ensure abuses do not arise. How external (environmental and health) costs are factored into program evaluation is partly dependent on the enabling legislation (or executive order). If the law establishes Renewable Portfolio Standards, the energy regulator will need to oversee the system and evaluate its effectiveness in meeting RE objectives. Generally, some other agency is responsible for certifying the generators and handling the certification system.
The sector regulator has a number of roles and responsibilities for operationalizing and implementing RE. The policy instruments include those oriented towards prices and quantities. The former (such as Feed-in Tariffs) provide the supplier with certainty regarding price, but the volume depends on whether that price is high or relatively low. The latter includes renewable portfolio standards that require distribution companies to purchase specific quantities of [[Electricity generation|electricity generated]] by renewable technologies.
In addition, the sector regulator is in a position to give advice to the government regarding the full implications of focusing on climate change or energy security. [[Policymakers]], however, may choose to delegate these decisions, or a subset of them, to regulators; on the other hand, they may choose to remain silent on such issues. In the former case, of course, regulators have the power to exercise their discretion. In the latter case, the scope of regulatory discretion depends on what the legal system provides. In either case, the internal practices followed by the regulator need to provide legitimacy for regulatory rulings related to RE. Such practices include transparency and evidence-based decision-making.<ref name="PURC">Frequently Asked Questions on Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency, Body of Knowledge on Infrastructure Regulation, [http://regulationbodyofknowledge.org/renewable-energy-and-energy-efficiency/]</ref>
== Renewable energy lawyers == '''Renewable energy lawyers''' focus their practice on serving the legal needs of renewable energy project developers and companies that develop clean technologies (see [[clean tech law]]).
==Renewable energy laws by country==
===Germany=== {{main|German Renewable Energy Sources Act}}
A chart summarizing German energy [[legislation]] is available.<ref name="bmwi-2016"> {{cite book | title = Overview of legislation governing Germany's energy supply system: key strategies, acts, directives, and regulations / ordinances | date = May 2016 | publisher = Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi) | place = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmwi.de/English/Redaktion/Pdf/gesetzeskarte,property=pdf,bereich=bmwi2012,sprache=en,rwb=true.pdf | access-date = 2016-04-29 }}</ref>
===Switzerland=== [[:de:Energiegesetz (Schweiz)]]
==Renewable energy laws by technology== Renewable energy laws can either be 'technology neutral' or provide specific assistance to particular selected groupings of renewable energy technology. Other aspects of land use planning law can have particular application to the implications of particular energy technologies, such as wind power.
=== Hydroelectric energy law ===
Conventional hydroelectric dams in most countries are highly regulated, with environmental reviews before construction and operational limits afterwards.<ref>https://www.ceaa-acee.gc.ca/050/documents/p63919/99173E.pdf</ref><ref>https://www.ferc.gov/industries/hydropower/gen-info/regulation/hydro-prog.asp</ref> Operation normally places river conditions before power interest, ie: power generation may not be needed at night while rivers are kept flowing.
=== Geothermal energy law === {{Main article|geothermal energy}}{{Empty section|date=February 2016}} Laws and Regulations Applicable to Geothermal Energy Development. ... A number of federal laws, regulations, and Executive Orders apply to geothermal energy development activities. For the most part, state laws and regulations do not apply to geothermal energy development on tribal lands

{{More citations needed|date=November 2008}} {{Infobox company | name = SGN | logo = SGN logo.svg | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2005 | location = [[Horley]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | key_people = John Morea ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]) | area_served = Scotland and the south of England | industry = [[Gas]] | products = Gas distribution | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = The company is owned by four shareholders – [[SSE plc]] (33.3%), Borealis Infrastructure Europe (UK) Limited (25%), which is indirectly wholly owned by OMERS Administration Corporation and OTPPB Investments (U.K.) Limited (25%), which is owned by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan Board, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (16.7%).<ref>https://www.sgn.co.uk/Publications/Annual-Reports/</ref> | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.sgn.co.uk www.sgn.co.uk] | footnotes = }}
'''SGN''' (previously known as '''Scotia Gas Networks''') is a UK gas distribution company which manages the network that distributes natural and [[green gas]] to 5.9 million homes and businesses across Scotland and the south of England.<ref>[https://www.sgn.co.uk/About-SGN/ SGN "About Us"]</ref> As of 2014/15 SGN operates more than 71,000 km of pipes. In the same period SGN spent £500 million on upgrading the network.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/network-regulation-riio-model/network-performance-under-riio/riio-gd1-performance-data|title = Ofgem RIIO model performance|date = 05/10/2015|accessdate = 2015-11-20|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== History == The company was formed in 2005 as Scotia Gas Networks. In September 2014 they changed their name to SGN. The rebrand was driven by a desire to present with a greater unity between the two distinct geographic areas of its business.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ENA - Gas distribution map|url = http://www.energynetworks.org/info/faqs/gas-distribution-map.html|website = www.energynetworks.org|accessdate = 2015-10-22}}</ref> Those are Scotland and the south of England, where SGN owns and maintains the gas network. The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority bought a 16.7% equity stake in SGN in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.swfinstitute.org/swf-article/adia-acquires-minority-stake-in-scotia-gas-networks/|title = ADIA Acquires Minority Stake in Scotia Gas Networks|publisher = Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute|accessdate = 2016-10-23}}</ref>
== 2014 Rebrand == In 2014, '''Scotia Gas Networks''', '''Scotland Gas Networks''' and '''Southern Gas Networks''' were rebranded to '''SGN'''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.smarternetworks.org/Files/Opening_up_the_Gas_Market_141014154845.pdf|title = Energy Networks Association: Smarter Networks|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The company believed the previous names did not represent the business as "bright, forward thinking experts", and that the name "SGN" would be better for customers to understand what SGN does as a company.
The logo was also changed. From 2005, the logo was originally red and blue dots forming a shape of the United Kingdom. The red dots covered Scotland and the southern area on the "Scotia Gas Networks" logo, just Scotland for the "Scotland Gas Networks" logo and just the southern area for "Southern Gas Networks". This was to highlight where works are carried out by the company. The new logo shows a cylinder filled with orange, blue and purple dots.
== Funding for Innovation == In 2014 SGN was awarded funding from the industry regulator, [[Office of Gas and Electricity Markets|Ofgem]], to develop two projects. Opening up the Gas Market is an investigation into whether the British Gas Safety Regulations could be changed to accept different types of gas. Robotics is a project to develop technology for repairing steel mains without interrupting the gas.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/network-regulation-riio-model/network-innovation/gas-network-innovation-competition/sgn|title = Ofgem Gas Network Innovation Competition|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Corporate Social Responsibility == A partnership between [[Girlguiding]] and SGN is designed to encourage young women into male dominated industries and also spread a message about gas safety and [[carbon monoxide]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = SGN - Scotia Gas Network|url = http://new.girlguiding.org.uk/what-is-girlguiding/our-partners/partner-profile-sgn|website = new.girlguiding.org.uk|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> SGN also works with [http://www.royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk/ Royal Voluntary Service] to produce a leaflet for winter safety, targeting the elderly.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Royal Voluntary Service {{!}} Corporate partners {{!}} SGN|url = http://www.royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk/fundraise/corporate-fundraising/corporate-partners/sgn|website = www.royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref>

A '''slushflow''' is rapid mass movement of [[water]] and [[snow]], and is categorized as a type of [[debris flow]]. Slushflows are caused when water reaches a critical concentration in the [[snowpack]] due to more water inflow than outflow. The high water concentration weakens the [[Cohesion (chemistry)|cohesion]] of the snow crystals and increases the weight of the snowpack. A slushflow is released when the component of the force of gravity parallel to the slope generates a [[hydraulic]] pressure gradient exceeding the tensile strength and basal friction of the snowpack.
While frequently compared to an [[avalanche]], they have some key differences. Slushflows are lower in frequency than avalanches, have higher water content, are more [[laminar flow|laminar]] in flow, and have lower [[velocity]]. They most commonly occur at higher [[latitude]]s in the winter during high [[precipitation]] and in the spring during high snowmelt. Because of their high water content, they can flow down gentle slopes of only a few degrees at low altitudes. They are a significant hazard in [[Norway]] and [[Iceland]]<ref>US National Research Council (1990) [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=1571&page=12 ''Snow Avalanche Hazards and Mitigation in the United States''] National Academies Press {{ISBN|978-0-309-04335-9}} pg 12</ref> and are responsible for the deaths of dozens of people as well as the destruction of buildings and the closure of roads.

{{Cleanup|reason=Needs trimming for OR/unsourced claims, improve references, editing for style/flow|date=June 2018}}[[File:QPEC Figure1.png|thumb|Quantum photoelectrochemistry calculation of photoinduced interfacial electron transfer in a dye-sensitized solar cell.]] '''Solar energy conversion''' describes technologies devoted to the transformation of solar energy to other (useful) forms of energy, including electricity, fuel, and heat.<ref>Crabtree, G. W.; Lewis, N. S. (2007). "Solar Energy Conversion". Physics Today 60, 3, 37. doi:10.1063/1.2718755.</ref> It covers light-harvesting technologies including traditional [[semiconductor]] [[photovoltaic]] devices (PVs), emerging photovoltaics,<ref>Light-Induced Redox Reactions in Nanocrystalline Systems, Anders Hagfeldt and Michael Graetzel, Chem. Rev., 95, 1, 49-68 (1995)</ref><ref>Materials interface engineering for solution-processed photovoltaics, Michael Graetzel, René A. J. Janssen, David B. Mitzi, Edward H. Sargent, Nature (insight review) 488, 304–312 (2012) doi:10.1038/nature11476 </ref><ref>Semiconductor Photochemistry And Photophysics, Vol. 10, V Ramamurthy, Kirk S Schanze, CRC Press, {{ISBN|9780203912294}} (2003)</ref> [[solar fuel]] generation via [[electrolysis]], [[artificial photosynthesis]], and related forms of [[photocatalysis]] directed at the generation of energy rich molecules.<ref>Magnuson, Ann; Anderlund, Magnus; Johansson, Olof; Lindblad, Peter; Lomoth, Reiner; Polivka, Tomas; Ott, Sascha; Stensjö, Karin; Styring, Stenbjörn; Sundström, Villy; Hammarström, Leif (December 2009). "Biomimetic and Microbial Approaches to Solar Fuel Generation". Accounts of Chemical Research 42 (12): 1899–1909. doi:10.1021/ar900127h.</ref>
Fundamental electro-optical aspects in several emerging solar energy conversion technologies for generation of both electricity (photovoltaics) and solar fuels constitute an active area of current research.<ref>Ponseca Jr., Carlito S.; Chábera, Pavel; Uhlig, Jens; Persson, Petter; Sundström, Villy (August 2017). "Ultrafast Electron Dynamics in Solar Energy Conversion". Chemical Reviews 117 : 10940–11024. doi:10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00807.</ref>
== History == Solar cells started in 1876 with William Grylls Adams along with an undergraduate student of his. A French scientist, by the name of [[Edmond Becquerel]], first discovered the photovoltaic effect in the summer of 1839.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Belessiotis & Papanicolaou|first=V.G & E.|date=2012|title=History of Solar Energy|url=|journal=Comprehensive Renewable Energy|volume=3|pages=85–102|via=}}</ref> He theorized that certain elements on the periodic table, such as silicon, reacted to the exposure of sunlight in very unusual ways. [[Solar power]] is created when solar radiation is converted to heat or electricity. English electrical engineer [[Willoughby Smith]], between 1873 and 1876, discovered that when selenium is exposed to light, it produced a high amount of electricity. The use of selenium was highly inefficient, but it proved Becquerel’s theory that light could be converted into electricity through the use of various semi-metals on the periodic table, that were later labeled as [[Photoconductivity|photo-conductive]] material. By 1953, Calvin Fuller, Gerald Pearson, and Daryl Chapin, discovered the use of silicon to produce solar cells was extremely efficient and produced a net charge that far exceeded that of selenium. Today solar power has many uses, from heating, electrical production, thermal processes, water treatment and storage of power that is highly prevalent in the world of renewable energy.
== Background == By the 1960’s solar power was the standard for powering space-bound satellites. Early 1970’s solar cell technology became cheaper and more available ($20/watt). Between 1970 and 1990, solar power became more commercially operated. Railroad crossings, oil rigs, space stations, microwave towers, aircraft, etc. Now, houses and businesses all over the world use solar cells to power electrical devices with a wide variety of uses. Solar power is the dominant technology in the renewable energy field, primarily due to its high efficiency and cost-effectiveness. By the early 90’s, photovoltaic conversion had reached an unprecedented new height. Scientists used solar cells constructed of highly conductive photovoltaic materials such as gallium, indium, phosphide and gallium arsenide that increased total efficiency by over 30%. By the end of the century, scientists created a special type of solar cells that converted upwards of 36% of the sunlight it collected into usable energy. These developments built tremendous momentum for not only solar power, but for [[Renewable energy|renewable]] energy technologies around the world.
== Electricity Production == Photovoltaics (PV) use silicon solar cells to convert the energy of sunlight into electricity. They operate under the photoelectric effect which results in the emission of electrons. Concentrated solar power (CSP) uses lenses or mirrors and tracking devices to focus a large area of sunlight into a small beam. Solar power is anticipated to be the world’s largest source of electricity by 2050. Solar power plants, such as Ivanpah Solar Power Facility in the Mojave Desert, produce over 392MW of power. Solar projects exceeding 1 GW (1 billion watts) are in development and are anticipated to be the future of solar power in the US.
== Thermal Energy == The heat collected by the sun is highly intensive and radioactive. The sun bombards the earth with billions of charged nanoparticles with an immense amount of energy stored in them. This heat can be used for water heating, space heating, space cooling and process heat generation. Many [[Steam generator (boiler)|steam generation]] systems have adapted to using sunlight as a primary source for heating feed water, a development that has greatly increased the overall efficiency of boilers and many other types of waste heat recovery systems. Solar cookers use sunlight for cooking, drying and [[pasteurization]]. Solar distillation is used for water treatment processes to create potable drinking water, which has been an extremely powerful player in providing countries in need with relief efforts through the use of advancing technology.
== Electricity Production == [[Photovoltaics]] (PV) use silicon solar cells to convert the energy of sunlight into electricity. Operates under the photoelectric effect which results in the emission of electrons.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-01-01|title=Spectroscopy and solar energy – in honor to Professor Renata Reisfeld|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022231316318944|journal=Journal of Luminescence|language=en|volume=193|pages=10–12|doi=10.1016/j.jlumin.2017.05.041|issn=0022-2313}}</ref> Concentrated solar power (CSP) Uses lenses or mirrors and tracking devices to focus a large area of sunlight into a small beam. Solar power is anticipated to be the world’s largest source of electricity by 2050. Solar power plants, such as Ivanpah Solar Power Facility in the Mojave Desert produces over 392MW of power. Solar projects exceeding 1 GW (1 billion watts) are in development and are anticipated to be the future of solar power in the US
== Economic Development == Very cost-effective technology. Solar installations are becoming cheaper and more readily available to countries where energy demand is high, but supply is low due to economic circumstances. Provide areas affected by natural disaster with cheap, clean energy. 1 Gigawatt solar power plants can produce almost 10 times as much power as a fossil fuel combustion power plant for more than half the cost.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|date=2015-11-01|title=The environmental and cost implications of solar energy preferences in Renewable Portfolio Standards|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421515300069|journal=Energy Policy|language=en|volume=86|pages=250–261|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2015.06.039|issn=0301-4215}}</ref> Projected to be the leader of energy production by the year 2050.
== Societal Impact == Creates jobs for local communities. Construction, design and operation of solar power facilities. Provides clean energy for hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses. Drastically reduces the cost for energy consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/dam/aplaws/publication/en/publications/environment-energy/www-ee-library/sustainable-energy/world-energy-assessment-energy-and-the-challenge-of-sustainability/World%20Energy%20Assessment-2000.pdf|title=Energy and Social Issues|last=Reddy & Holdren & Khatib & Turkenburg|first=Amuyla & John & Hisham & Wim|date=2000|website=United Nations Development Programme|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Environmental Impact == Installations can destroy and/or relocate ecological habitats.<ref name=":0" /> Covers and huge amount of area that may be protected land Solar facilities constructed on Indian reservations have interrupted Native American traditions, practices and the lives of various animal life on the reservations. Causes some degree of direct and/or indirect defragmenting of various habitats.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hernandez|first=Rebecca R.|last2=Hoffacker|first2=Madison K.|last3=Murphy-Mariscal|first3=Michelle L.|last4=Wu|first4=Grace C.|last5=Allen|first5=Michael F.|date=2015-11-03|title=Solar energy development impacts on land cover change and protected areas|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/112/44/13579|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=112|issue=44|pages=13579–13584|doi=10.1073/pnas.1517656112|issn=0027-8424|pmid=26483467|pmc=4640750}}</ref>
== Future of the industry == Overview of the basic science, construction, design and operation of solar technologies. Societal, environmental, economic and local community impacts that solar technology can have. Projections/future of renewable energy, specifically solar power, around the world. Increased standards of living, population control, readily available energy supplies, increased technological and scientific development among third world countries. Significantly reduced emissions and pollution in Earth’s atmosphere.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www1.eere.energy.gov/solar/pdfs/42169.pdf|title=Improving Air Quality with Solar Energy|last=Beckley|first=Dan|date=|website=eere|archive-url=|archive-date=2007|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><gallery> File:Photovoltaic power station diagram.svg </gallery>

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2011}} [[File:Steam-powered fire engine.jpg|thumb|Preserved British steam-powered [[fire engine]] – an example of a mobile [[steam engine]]. This is a [[horse-drawn vehicle]]: the [[steam engine]] drives the [[water pump]]]] '''Steam pumper fire engines''' were used roughly from 1840 to 1920 to pump water on city fires. Large urban [[fire departments]] would invest in fire brigades, or engine companies, to assist in fire fighting. Concomitant with the [[steam engine]] would be a house, horses and dalmatian dogs (used to guide and calm the horses). The growing cities in the US west would invest in steam pumpers usually after a devastating fire that would destroy large parts of the wooden frontier town.
The first steam pumper was built by Braithwaite and Ericcson in England in 1829. In the following decades, European cities invested in steam powered fire equipment.
The vertical fast firing boilers, while heavy, was an effective fire fighting equipment. For a few years, c. 1910-20, the horses were retired and the steam pumper was hauled by a gas tractor.
Small two wheel units for hand movement were built in [[England]] to help fight incendiary fires during the [[Luftwaffe]] [[The Blitz|Blitz]].
A few builders were American: [[Waterous Engine Works Co. Ltd.|Waterous]], Amoskeag; [[Merryweather & Sons|Merryweather]] and [[Shand Mason]] were London-based fire engine manufacturers.

{{merge to|Topological insulator|date=July 2018}} A topological insulator (TI) is a material that has a nontrivial [[symmetry]], protected by a [[Topological sorting|topological ordering]] at the surface whiles the interior behaves as an insulator. This ordering is observed when electrons that are subject to strong external magnetic field, exhibit electronic excitation gap in the sample bulk and metallic conduction at the boundaries or surfaces.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hsieh|first=D.|last2=Qian|first2=D.|last3=Wray|first3=L.|last4=Xia|first4=Y.|last5=Hor|first5=Y. S.|last6=Cava|first6=R. J.|last7=Hasan|first7=M. Z.|date=2008|title=A topological Dirac insulator in a quantum spin Hall phase|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature06843|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=452|issue=7190|pages=970–974|doi=10.1038/nature06843|issn=0028-0836|via=}}</ref> The metallic conduction are dictated by the conventional charge [[quantum Hall effect]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tsui|first=D. C.|last2=Stormer|first2=H. L.|last3=Gossard|first3=A. C.|date=1982-05-31|title=Two-Dimensional Magnetotransport in the Extreme Quantum Limit|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.48.1559|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=48|issue=22|pages=1559–1562|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.48.1559}}</ref> The surface has a two dimensional symmetry and the ordering on the surface is due to the strong [[magnetic field]] on the electrons confined to the surface. Figure 1 is a schematic of the conduction, valence band and the surface state of a topological insulator.The electronic band structure is typical to that of an insulator with the Fermi level in between the valence and conduction band. [[File:Topology azeema.jpg|alt=|thumb|Band structure of topological insulator]]Topological ordering has also been observed in three dimensional (3D) materials. In contrast to their 2D counterparts, the role of the magnetic field in3D topological insulators is assumed by the spin-orbit coupling, which is an inherent property of all solids.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Moore|first=Joel E.|date=2010|title=The birth of topological insulators|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature08916|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=464|issue=7286|pages=194–198|doi=10.1038/nature08916|issn=0028-0836|via=}}</ref> The distinction between 2D and 3D topological insulators is characterized by the Z-2 topological invariant, which defines the ground state. In 2D, there is a single Z-2 invariant distinguishing the insulator from the quantum spin-Hall phase whiles in 3D, there are four Z-2 invariant that differentiate the insulator from “weak” and “strong” topological insulators.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Fu|first=Liang|last2=Kane|first2=C. L.|date=2007-07-02|title=Topological insulators with inversion symmetry|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.76.045302|journal=Physical Review B|volume=76|issue=4|pages=045302|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.76.045302|arxiv=cond-mat/0611341}}</ref>
== Prediction and discovery ==
The predictions that led to the [[Topological insulator|discovery of topological insulators]] date back in the 1980s. It was discovered that electrons that are confined to two dimensions and subject to strong magnetic field show a different topological ordering, which underlies the quantum Hall effect.<ref name=":0" /> The effect of this topological ordering results in the emergence of particles with fractional charges and non-[[dissipation]] transport. The distinguishing features of topological materials stems in the fact that they are insulating (have energy gaps) in the bulk but have a "protected" metallic properties (gapless) at the edge or surface state [5]. These "protected" gapless states are governed by the [[T-symmetry|time-reversal symmetry]] and the band structure of the material.
== Experimental realization ==
The first topological insulator to be realized experimentally was [[Bismuth antimonide|Bi<sub>1 − x</sub> Sb <sub>x</sub>]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Hasan|first=M. Zahid|last2=Moore|first2=Joel E.|date=2011|title=Three-Dimensional Topological Insulators|url=https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-062910-140432|journal=Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics|language=en|volume=2|issue=1|pages=55–78|doi=10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-062910-140432|issn=1947-5454|via=}}</ref> Bismuth in its pure state, is a [[semimetal]] with a small electronic band gap. Using [[Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy|angle- resolved photoemission spectroscopy]], and other measurements, it was observed that Bi<sub>1 − x</sub>Sb<sub>x</sub> alloy exhibits an odd [[Surface states|surface state]] (SS) crossing between any pair of [[Kramers theorem|Kramers]] points.<ref name=":2" /> Additionally, bulk Bi<sub>1 − x</sub>Sb<sub>x</sub> has been predicted to have 3D [[Dirac particle]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buot|first=F. A.|date=1973-09-01|title=Weyl Transform and the Magnetic Susceptibility of a Relativistic Dirac Electron Gas|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevA.8.1570|journal=Physical Review A|volume=8|issue=3|pages=1570–1581|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.8.1570}}</ref> This prediction is of particular interest due to the observation of charge [[Fractional quantum Hall effect|quantum Hall fractionalization]] in 2D graphene <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kane|first=C. L.|last2=Mele|first2=E. J.|date=2005-11-23|title=Quantum Spin Hall Effect in Graphene|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.226801|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=95|issue=22|pages=226801|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.226801}}</ref> and pure bismuth.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Behnia|first=Kamran|last2=Balicas|first2=Luis|last3=Kopelevich|first3=Yakov|date=2007-09-21|title=Signatures of Electron Fractionalization in Ultraquantum Bismuth|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/317/5845/1729|journal=Science|language=en|volume=317|issue=5845|pages=1729–1731|doi=10.1126/science.1146509|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17702909}}</ref>
Topological ordering with the help of ARPES, has also been observed in other materials such as bismuth telluride <ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=Xi|last2=Ma|first2=Xu-Cun|last3=He|first3=Ke|last4=Jia|first4=Jin-Feng|last5=Xue|first5=Qi-Kun|date=2011-03-01|title=Molecular Beam Epitaxial Growth of Topological Insulators|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/adma.201003855|journal=Advanced Materials|language=en|volume=23|issue=9|pages=1162–1165|doi=10.1002/adma.201003855|issn=0935-9648|via=}}</ref> and bismuth selenide.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiatti|first=Olivio|last2=Riha|first2=Christian|last3=Lawrenz|first3=Dominic|last4=Busch|first4=Marco|last5=Dusari|first5=Srujana|last6=Sánchez-Barriga|first6=Jaime|last7=Mogilatenko|first7=Anna|last8=Yashina|first8=Lada V.|last9=Valencia|first9=Sergio|date=2016-06-07|title=2D layered transport properties from topological insulator Bi2Se3 single crystals and micro flakes|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/srep27483|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=6|issue=1|doi=10.1038/srep27483|issn=2045-2322}}</ref>
== Growth of topological insulators == Topological insulators can be grown using different methods such as [[Metal organic chemical vapor deposition|metal-organic chemical vapor deposition]] (MOCVD),<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alegria|first=L. D.|last2=Schroer|first2=M. D.|last3=Chatterjee|first3=A.|last4=Poirier|first4=G. R.|last5=Pretko|first5=M.|last6=Patel|first6=S. K.|last7=Petta|first7=J. R.|date=2012-08-06|title=Structural and Electrical Characterization of Bi2Se3 Nanostructures Grown by Metal–Organic Chemical Vapor Deposition|url=https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/nl302108r|journal=Nano Letters|language=EN|volume=12|issue=9|pages=4711–4714|doi=10.1021/nl302108r|issn=1530-6984}}</ref> solvothermal synthesis,<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-06-01|title=Preparation and characterization of wire-like Sb2Se3 and flake-like Bi2Se3 nanocrystals|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022024803010194|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|language=en|volume=253|issue=1-4|pages=445–451|doi=10.1016/S0022-0248(03)01019-4|issn=0022-0248}}</ref> sonochemical technique <ref>{{Cite journal|date=2004-11-15|title=Sonochemical synthesis of bismuth selenide nanobelts at room temperature|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022024804009625|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|language=en|volume=271|issue=3-4|pages=456–461|doi=10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2004.08.015|issn=0022-0248}}</ref> and [[molecular beam epitaxy]] [[File:Molecular Beam Epitaxy.png|thumb|250x250px|Schematic of the components of a MBE system]] (MBE).<ref name=":3" /> MBE has so far been the most common experimental technique used in the growth of topological insulators. The growth of thin film topological insulators is governed by weak Van der Waals interactions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jerng|first=Sahng-Kyoon|last2=Joo|first2=Kisu|last3=Kim|first3=Youngwook|last4=Yoon|first4=Sang-Moon|last5=Lee|first5=Jae Hong|last6=Kim|first6=Miyoung|last7=Kim|first7=Jun Sung|last8=Yoon|first8=Euijoon|last9=Chun|first9=Seung-Hyun|date=2013|title=Ordered growth of topological insulator Bi2Se3 thin films on dielectric amorphous SiO2 by MBE|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/Content/ArticleLanding/2013/NR/c3nr03032f|journal=Nanoscale|language=en|volume=5|issue=21|pages=10618|doi=10.1039/C3NR03032F|issn=2040-3364}}</ref> The weak interaction allows to exfoliate the thin film from bulk crystal with a clean and perfect surface. The Van der Waals interactions in epitaxy also known as Van der Waals epitaxy (VDWE), is a phenomenon governed by weak Van der Waal’s interactions between layered materials of different or same elements <ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Geim|first=A. K.|last2=Grigorieva|first2=I. V.|date=2013|title=Van der Waals heterostructures|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature12385|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=499|issue=7459|pages=419–425|doi=10.1038/nature12385|issn=0028-0836|via=}}</ref> in which the materials
are stacked on top of each other. This approach allows the growth of layered topological insulators on other substrates for [[Heterojunction|heterostructure]] and [[integrated circuit]]s.<ref name=":4" />
'''Molecular Beam Epitaxial (MBE) growth of topological insulators'''
MBE is an [[epitaxy]] method for the growth of a crystalline material on a crystalline substrate to form an ordered layer. MBE is performed in [[Vacuum|high vacuum]] or [[ultra-high vacuum]]. In solid states, the elements are heated in different electron beam evaporators until they [[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublime]]. The gaseous elements then condense on the wafer where they react with each other to form [[single crystal]]s. In the growth of [[thin film]] layers on a substrate, the reaction is through vapor deposition. By heating the elemental source material, the vapor pressure increases, reaching a critical value that leads
to the deposition of the source material onto the substrate. Both crystals then react with each other for the source material to form layered thin films on the substrate. MBE is an appropriate technique
for the growth of high quality single-crystal films. In order to avoid a huge [[Lattice constant#Lattice matching|lattice mismatch]] and [[Crystallographic defect|defects]] at the interface, the substrate and thin film are expected to have similar lattice constants. MBE has an advantage over other methods due to the fact that the synthesis is performed in high vacuum hence resulting in less contamination. Additionally, lattice defect is reduced due to the ability to influence the growth rate and the ratio of species of source materials present at the substrate interface.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Heremans|first=Joseph P.|last2=Cava|first2=Robert J.|last3=Samarth|first3=Nitin|date=2017-09-05|title=Tetradymites as thermoelectrics and topological insulators|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/natrevmats201749|journal=Nature Reviews Materials|language=En|volume=2|issue=10|pages=17049|doi=10.1038/natrevmats.2017.49|issn=2058-8437}}</ref> Furthermore, in MBE, samples can be grown layer by layer which results in flat surfaces with smooth interface for engineered heterostructures. Moreover, MBE synthesis technique benefits from the ease of moving a topological insulator sample from the growth chamber to a characterization chamber such as angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) or [[Scanning tunneling microscope|scanning tunneling microscopy]] (STM) studies.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wiley.com/en-us/Topological+Insulators:+Fundamentals+and+Perspectives-p-9783527337026|title=Topological Insulators: Fundamentals and Perspectives|date=2015-06-29|website=Wiley.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref>
Due to the weak Van der Waals bonding, which relaxes the lattice-matching condition, TI can be grown on a wide variety of substrates <ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=He|first=Liang|last2=Kou|first2=Xufeng|last3=Wang|first3=Kang L.|date=2013-01-31|title=Review of 3D topological insulator thin-film growth by molecular beam epitaxy and potential applications|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/pssr.201307003|journal=Physica Status Solidi RRL|language=en|volume=7|issue=1-2|pages=50–63|doi=10.1002/pssr.201307003|issn=1862-6254}}</ref> such as Si(111),<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2011-10-31|title=Epitaxial growth of topological insulator Bi2Se3 film on Si(111) with atomically sharp interface|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040609011014209|journal=Thin Solid Films|language=en|volume=520|issue=1|pages=224–229|doi=10.1016/j.tsf.2011.07.033|issn=0040-6090}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhang|first=Guanhua|last2=Qin|first2=Huajun|last3=Teng|first3=Jing|last4=Guo|first4=Jiandong|last5=Guo|first5=Qinlin|last6=Dai|first6=Xi|last7=Fang|first7=Zhong|last8=Wu|first8=Kehui|date=2009-08-03|title=Quintuple-layer epitaxy of thin films of topological insulator Bi2Se3|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.3200237|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=95|issue=5|pages=053114|doi=10.1063/1.3200237|issn=0003-6951}}</ref> Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> , GaAs(111),<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richardella|first=A.|last2=Zhang|first2=D. M.|last3=Lee|first3=J. S.|last4=Koser|first4=A.|last5=Rench|first5=D. W.|last6=Yeats|first6=A. L.|last7=Buckley|first7=B. B.|last8=Awschalom|first8=D. D.|last9=Samarth|first9=N.|date=2010-12-27|title=Coherent heteroepitaxy of Bi2Se3 on GaAs (111)B|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.3532845|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=97|issue=26|pages=262104|doi=10.1063/1.3532845|issn=0003-6951}}</ref>
InP(111), CdS(0001) and Y<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> .
== Bismuth-based topological insulators == Thus far, the field of topological insulators has been focused on bismuth and antimony [[chalcogenide]] based materials such as Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> , Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> , Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> or [[Bismuth antimonide|Bi<sub>1 − x</sub>Sb<sub>x</sub>]] . The choice of chalcogenides is related to the Van der Waals relaxation of the lattice matching strength which restricts the number of materials and substrates.<ref name=":5" /> Bismuth chalcogenides have been studied extensively for TIs and their applications in [[thermoelectric materials]]. The Van der Waals interaction in TIs exhibit important features due to low surface energy. For instance, the surface of Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> is usually terminated by Te due to its low surface energy.<ref name=":3" />
Bismuth chalcogenides have been successfully grown on different substrates. In particular, Si has been a good substrate for the successful growth of Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> . However, the use of sapphire as substrate has not been so encouraging due to a large mismatch of about 15%.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Ginley|first=Theresa P.|last2=Wang|first2=Yong|last3=Law|first3=Stephanie|date=2016-11-23|title=Topological Insulator Film Growth by Molecular Beam Epitaxy: A Review|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2073-4352/6/11/154|journal=Crystals|language=en|volume=6|issue=11|pages=154|doi=10.3390/cryst6110154}}</ref> The selection of appropriate substrate can improve the overall properties of TI. The use of buffer layer can reduce the lattice match hence improving the electrical properties of TI.<ref name=":6" /> Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> can be grown on top of various Bi<sub>1 − x</sub>In<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> buffers. Table 1 shows Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> , Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> , Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> on different substrates and the resulting lattice mismatch. Generally, regardless of the substrate
used, the resulting films have a textured surface that is characterized by pyramidal single-crystal domains with quintuple-layer steps. The size and relative proportion of these pyramidal domains vary with factors that include film thickness, lattice mismatch with the substrate and interfacial chemistry-dependent film nucleation. The synthesis of thin films have the stoichiometry problem due to the high vapor pressures of the elements. Thus, binary tetradymites are extrinsically doped as n-type (Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> , Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> ) or p-type (Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> ).<ref name=":5" />

== Characterization of topological insulators== The first step of topological insulators characterization takes place right after synthesis, meaning without breaking the vacuum and moving the sample to an atmosphere. It is important because a possible chemical reaction on the surface with the atmosphere can change the surface states. That could be done by using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) or scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) techniques.<ref name=":7" /> Further measurements includes structural and chemical probes such as X-ray diffraction and energy-dispersive spectroscopy but depending on the sample quality, the lack of sensitivity could remain. The most effective metric is the electrical transport measurements of resistivity, Hall effect, and magnetoresistance.<ref name=":7" />
== Future developments == It should be noted that the field of topological insulators still needs to be developed. The best bismuth chalcogenide topological insulators have about 10 meV bandgap variation due to the charge change. Further development should focus on the examination of both: the presence of high-symmetry electronic bands and simply synthesized materials. One of the promising candidates is [[Heusler compound|half-Heusler compounds]].<ref name=":7" /> These crystal structures can consist of a large number of elements. Band structures and energy gaps are very sensitive to the valence configuration; because of the increased likelihood of intersite exchange and disorder, they are also very sensitive to specific crystalline configurations. A nontrivial band structure that exhibits band ordering analogous to that of the known 2D and 3D TI materials was predicted in a variety of 18-electron half-Heusler compounds using first-principles calculations.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2013-04-01|title=Prediction of topological insulating behavior in inverse Heusler compounds from first principles|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025612007367|journal=Computational Materials Science|language=en|volume=70|pages=145–149|doi=10.1016/j.commatsci.2012.12.013|issn=0927-0256}}</ref>

== History == Sunrise Propane Industrial Gases was a company that sold [[propane]] for commercial and home purposes, in addition to other gases such as [[helium]] and [[acetylene]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.propanecanada.com/about.php |title=Sunrise Propane Industrial Gases |accessdate=2009-08-14|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j68cyUbL?url=http://www.propanecanada.com/about.php|archivedate=2009-08-17|deadurl=no}}</ref> The company has operated under a number of names since at least 1999. In 2002, a company named Sunrise Petroleum was successfully sued by First Choice Petroleum Inc., an [[oil]] and [[lubricant]]s supplier, that claimed the company owed them C$54,063.73 in products and that Sunrise had forged a document to avoid settling their account.<ref name="star propane issues">{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/article/476648 |publisher=TheStar.com |title=Propane firm had many names |date=2008-08-12 |accessdate=2009-08-14|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j68dOv35?url=http://www.thestar.com/article/476648|archivedate=2009-08-17|deadurl=no | location=Toronto | first=Nicole | last=Baute}}</ref> In that case, it was found that Sunrise had forged the signature of a First Choice employee named Thomas Tims in a 1999 document, which stated Sunrise Petroleum would be taken over by a new company called Sunrise Petroleum Lubricants, and that Sunrise Petroleum would thereby not be responsible for any outstanding, unpaid, or unsettled accounts. However, Tims would not have signed the document because he was listed on it as "Tim Toms", rather than Tom Tims. As a result of the case, Sunrise was forced to pay the account owed plus interest, totalling C$93,389.54, and an additional C$34,284.71 in legal fees. Court documents also revealed a third name, Sunrise Propane & Petroleum, that the company had previously used.<ref name="star propane issues" />
An Ontario corporate profile states the facility was [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in 2004, though a Sunrise corporate solicitor and spokesperson is uncertain how long the facility was in operation.<ref name="star propane issues" /> The facility was built in a residential neighbourhood in the North York area of Toronto. Toronto mayor [[David Miller (Canadian politician)|David Miller]] stated that the facility was allowed to be built in the neighbourhood under zoning that was in place for over a decade.<ref name="built">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2008/08/10/explosion-residents.html |title=Residents say propane facility had no place near houses |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-10 |accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
The facility had previously been warned by Ontario's Technical Standards and Safety Authority for its lack of safety by not stopping truck-to-truck transfers at the company's facilities. During the investigation following the explosions, investigators found that truck-to-truck transfers were common at the facility. Truck-to-truck transfers are prohibited in Ontario because they increase the risk of a [[gas leak]] or a fire.<ref name="illegal transfer" />
== Incident == [[Image:Propane Explosion in North Toronto.jpg|thumb|left|The explosion seen from the Keele overpass]] At approximately 03:50 ET on the morning of August 10, 2008, a large explosion occurred at Sunrise Propane Industrial Gases, located near Murray Road and Spalding Road. This was followed by a series of explosions which sent large fireballs and clouds of smoke billowing into the sky. Large pieces of metal from the exploding propane tanks were ejected onto nearby streets and properties. Many homes and offices were damaged, windows were shattered, and doors were ripped from their hinges. About 200 firefighters battled the [[Multiple-alarm fire|seven-alarm fire]] that resulted from the explosions.<ref name="firefighter death" />
The threat of further blasts and concerns about the air quality forced the police to conduct a voluntary [[emergency evacuation|evacuation]] of a large area in the surrounding community. Residents living within a {{convert|1.6|km|0}} radius were told to leave their homes in the early hours of the morning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.citynews.ca/news/news_25625.aspx |title=Firefighter Found Without Vital Signs Succumbs Following Massive Blast |work=CityNews |publisher=Rogers Broadcasting Ltd. |accessdate=2008-08-11 |date=2008-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813035812/http://www.citynews.ca/news/news_25625.aspx |archivedate=2008-08-13 |df= }}</ref> [[Toronto Transit Commission]] buses were used to evacuate them to [[Downsview Park]] and then to [[York University]].<ref name="star" />
The explosions rocked the area and also caused the closure of part of [[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]], between highways [[Ontario Highway 404|404]] and [[Ontario Highway 400|400]], for over 12 hours.<ref name="ctvnews">{{cite episode |title=CTV News |network=[[CTV Television Network|CTV]] |station=[[CFTO-TV|CTV Toronto]] |airdate=2008-08-10}}</ref> Emergency crews feared another major explosion as two rail [[tank car|tankers]] continued to burn more than five hours after the initial explosion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/Front/9007904.html |title=Thousands evacuated in Toronto after explosions at propane facility |publisher=[[The Chronicle Herald]] |date=2008-08-10 |accessdate=2008-08-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Regular commercial air traffic was allowed to continue in and out of [[Pearson International Airport]] while smaller, privately owned aircraft were restricted from flying over the area.<ref name="firefighter death" />
Six people were sent to the hospital, 18 people admitted themselves to emergency clinics, and Emergency Medical Services treated 40 people on the site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080811/to_explo_080812/20080812?hub=TopStories |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date=2008-08-12 |accessdate=2008-08-12 |title=Coroner investigates after body found at blast site}}</ref> During the course of the emergency response to the scene, a Toronto [[firefighter]] was found lifeless by emergency crews. [[Paramedic]]s and firefighters tried to revive him but were unsuccessful. He was then rushed to a [[hospital]] where he was pronounced dead. The firefighter was identified as Bob Leek, a 55-year-old district chief of emergency planning and a 25-year veteran.<ref name="firefighter death" /> Leek, who was off duty that night, had been asked to bring some equipment to aid the activities of his colleagues, which he gladly did. He just happened to have had a heart attack at that time. Sunrise employee Parminder Saini was unaccounted for. On August 11, a [[Dead body|body]] was found at the scene. On September 3, the body was confirmed to be that of Saini.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080810/to_explo_080810?s_name=&no_ads= |title=Thousands returning home after massive T.O. fire |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date=2008-08-10 |accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/14/saini-propane.html |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-14 |accessdate=2008-08-14 |title=Employee missing from propane plant is student from India}}</ref>
== Cause and investigation == The Ontario Fire Marshal's Office handled the investigation of the explosions.<ref name="firefighter death" /> While the cause of the explosions has not yet been determined, on August 21, 2008, Ontario's independent safety regulator for fuels, the Technical Standards and Safety Authority, released a statement saying that just before the explosion, a truck driver was illegally transferring propane from one truck to another. The agency also reported that in November 2006, Sunrise Propane was warned about its lack of safety by not stopping the truck-to-truck transfers at the company's facilities, and that truck-to-truck transfers were a frequent and routine operating practice at the facility.<ref name="illegal transfer" /> An investigator with the Ontario Fire Marshal's Office stated that it could take months before the cause of the explosions could be determined. [[Premier of Ontario|Ontario Premier]] [[Dalton McGuinty]] also said that the province was willing to provide financial aid to residents whose homes were damaged by the explosions.<ref name="length">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/18/fmo-propane.html |date=2008-08-18 |accessdate=2008-08-19 |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |title=Determining cause of propane blast could take months}}</ref>
On August 4, 2010, the [[Toronto Star]] reported that the massive Sunrise propane explosion in 2008 was caused by an illegal "tank-to-tank transfer" along with a gas hose leak. The report said that liquid propane was released from a hose after a "tank-to-tank transfer" was completed. The Star reports that Sunrise didn't have the right licence to perform those types of transfers, and it was previously barred from doing so by the [[Technical Standards and Safety Authority]] in November 2006.<ref>http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100804/100804_sunrise_cause/20100804/?hub=CP24Home</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/843631--sunrise-blast-caused-by-illegal-tank-to-tank-transfer-report-says?bn=1 | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Jasmeet | last=Sidhu | title=Sunrise blast caused by illegal ‘tank-to-tank transfer,' report says | date=2010-08-03}}</ref>
The [[Minister of the Environment (Canada)|Environment Ministry]] has argued that Sunrise failed "to show that there was a proper preventative maintenance system in place."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/06/12/sunrise-propane-must-be-penalized-for-massive-downsview-explosion-government-lawyer/ | location=Toronto | work=The National Post | first=Megan | last=O'Toole | title=Sunrise Propane must be penalized for massive Downsview explosion: government lawyer | date=2012-06-12}}</ref> Leo Adler, Sunrise's lawyer, argued that the event was an unforeseeable accident because Sunrise kept their equipment in good order and cannot be held responsible for a hose failure.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/crime/article/1209697--sunrise-propane-trial-fatal-explosion-a-tragic-accident-defence-says-in-closing-arguments | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Valerie | last=Hauch | title=Sunrise Propane trial: Fatal explosion a "tragic accident," defence says in closing arguments | date=2012-06-11}}</ref><ref>[http://crimlawcanada.com/media/adler "Leo Adler in the Media"]</ref>
== Aftermath == [[File:Evacuated Highway 401 Color.jpg|thumb|left|[[Highway 401]] was closed due to its proximity to the explosion.]] Due to its proximity to the site, [[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]] was shut down from [[Ontario Highway 404|Highway 404]] to [[Ontario Highway 400|Highway 400]], and the local [[Yorkdale Shopping Centre|Yorkdale Mall]] was closed for part of the day.<ref name=globe/> [[Toronto Transit Commission]] routes and the [[York Region Transit]] [[Viva (bus rapid transit)|Viva]] [[Viva Orange|Orange]] route were affected as a result of evacuation zone. Bus routes were diverted and a section of the [[Yonge-University-Spadina]] subway line between [[Downsview Station]] and [[Lawrence West (TTC)|Lawrence West Station]] was shut down for part of the day. [[GO Transit]] services to [[Yorkdale Bus Terminal]] were also suspended.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20080810/080810_explosion_closures/20080810/?hub=CP24Home |title=List of closures as a result of the explosions |work=CP24.com |publisher=[[CTVglobemedia]] |accessdate=2008-08-11 |date=2008-08-10}}</ref>
About 15 hours after the first explosions, some residents were given the go-ahead to return to their homes. However, many people returning to their homes were stopped at police checkpoints and turned back, or not permitted to take their vehicles into the immediate area.<ref name="ctvnews"/> Approximately 100 of the 12,000 evacuated homes were left uninhabitable.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20080810/to_explo_080811/20080811/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=100 homes uninhabitable after blast: T.O. police |work=CTV News |publisher=[[CTV News]] |accessdate=2008-08-11 |date=2008-08-11}}</ref><ref name="cbc aug 11">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/11/tto-fire.html |title=Almost all Toronto residents back home after propane blast |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-11 |accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref> On August 11, almost all residents who had to be evacuated were allowed back, though about 35 families had to wait while tests by health officials were conducted over concerns about airborne [[asbestos]].<ref name="cbc aug 11" />
As a result of the explosion, Toronto officials plan on reviewing all industrial areas that could pose a potential threat to residential neighbourhoods to prevent similar situations. As part of its investigation, TSSA officials and the Ontario Fire Marshal are reviewing past inspections of the facility to determine the cause of the explosions.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/11/propane-fire.html |title=Toronto to review zoning bylaws after propane explosion, fire |date=2008-08-11 |accessdate=2008-08-11 |publisher=[[CBC.ca]]}}</ref>
The explosion caused damage to one of Toronto's oldest Jewish [[cemetery|cemeteries]], the Mount Sinai Memorial Park. The cemetery is over 100 years old and has more than 11,000 graves, of which at least 20 were damaged.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/11/mount-sinai.html |title=Historic Jewish cemetery closed by propane accident |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-11 |accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
Various residents were angry because the municipal government allowed Sunrise to build a propane facility in a residential area. Some residents claim that the community was not consulted or notified about the facility when it was being built. However, [[Shelley Carroll]], Toronto's acting deputy mayor, suggested that the facility had been zoned before many of the homes were built.<ref name="built" />
The Technical Standards and Safety Authority, the agency that regulates fuel safety in Ontario, originally said that it had only inspected Sunrise once since it opened in 2005. They later contradicted this by stating that they had issued stop work orders in 2006 and 2007 over safety violations.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/14/tssa-propane.html |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-14 |accessdate=2008-08-14 |title=Propane plant cited for violations in 2006 and 2007}}</ref>
On August 19, nine days after the explosions, Sunrise issued a short news release, stating that the company regrets the loss of life and that they were co-operating with authorities' investigations. The news release also said that they would not be making any more public comments in the near future to prevent speculation and misinformation.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/19/propane-sunrise.html |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-19 |accessdate=2008-08-19 |title=Propane company urges public not to rush to judgment}}</ref> On August 21, 2008 the TSSA issued a notice that Sunrise Propane should immediately have its authorization revoked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sse.gov.on.ca/mcs/en/Pages/Propane_Safety_Update.aspx |title=An Update On Propane Safety In Ontario |publisher=Ministry of Consumer Services, Province of Ontario |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402051213/http://www.sse.gov.on.ca/mcs/en/Pages/Propane_Safety_Update.aspx |archivedate=2012-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
Six other propane facilities in the province have been shut down as a result of an audit prompted by the explosions. Facilities in [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]], [[Waterloo, Ontario|Waterloo]], [[Cornwall, Ontario|Cornwall]], [[Ottawa]], and two in Toronto have been ordered to shut down after failing to show that their employees were properly trained at the facilities.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080822/propane_folo_080822/20080822?hub=Canada |publisher=CTV |date=2008-08-22 |accessdate=2008-08-22 |title=Investigators find possible cause of propane blast}}</ref>
Parminder Saini's father was granted a [[Visa (document)|visa]] to travel from Punjab to Canada to aid in the investigation, although Parminder's brother and mother were denied by the Canadian Consulate. This decision was later changed after the Department of Citizenship and Immigration was informed of the situation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2008/08/27/saini-propane.html |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] |date=2008-08-27 |accessdate=2008-08-27 |title=Family of missing Sunrise Propane employee given visas}}</ref>
Felipe De Leon, an employee at Sunrise, stated that he had completed an illegal propane transfer when he noticed smoke at the north end of the facility. De Leon said he then went inside the facility's office to warn Saini to flee the building, but he refused. De Leon then fled from the facility while Parminder walked towards the smoke.<ref name="illegal transfer" />
Cleaning up the result of the explosion cost the city of Toronto $CAD 1.8 million, half of which was paid by the province of Ontario.<ref name="cbc 08/09" />
== Charges laid == On August 5, 2009, the [[Ontario Ministry of Labour]] laid two charges in the incident. One of the charges relates to the failure of protecting Saini. The other charge alleges that the company failed to operate within mandatory industry standards. If convicted, the company could be fined up to C$1 million.<ref>[http://www.cp24.com/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090805/090805_sunrise_propane/20090805/?hub=CP24Home Police charge Sunrise Propane after last year's deadly explosion] www.cp24.com, published August 5, 2009</ref> Additionally, the residents filed a $300 million lawsuit.<ref>[http://www.canada.com/Toronto+propane+company+faces+charges+explosion/1864276/story.html Toronto Propane Company Faces Charges For Explosion] www.canada.com, published August 5, 2009. Accessed 2009-08-07. [https://www.webcitation.org/5ixIeN4R9?url=http://www.canada.com/Toronto%2Bpropane%2Bcompany%2Bfaces%2Bcharges%2Bexplosion/1864276/story.html Archived] 2009-08-11.</ref> On June 27, 2013, Sunrise Propane was found guilty of nine non-criminal charges.<ref>[http://toronto.ctvnews.ca/sunrise-propane-found-guilty-in-massive-2008-toronto-explosion-1.1343783] ctvnews.ca, published June 27, 2013</ref> On January 25, 2016, Sunrise Propane and its directors Shay Ben-Moshe and Valery Belahov were fined $5.3 million for the offenses. Sunrise was no longer in operation at the time and the defence lawyer argued his clients did not have the money to pay millions in fines.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[CBC News]]|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/sunrise-propane-fined-1.3419010|title=Sunrise Propane, directors fined $5.3M for deadly explosion|date=25 January 2016}}</ref>
{{Wikinews|Massive explosion in North Toronto, Ontario}}
== See also == * [[1979 Mississauga train derailment]]: the last large-scale explosion, fire, and evacuation in the greater Toronto area prior to the Sunrise blast.
